qas.question: Name one major group that Jews are often identified as belonging to.
Name another major group that Jews are often identified as belonging to?
What does Ashkenaz mean in Hebrew?
What is the more common term in Israel for many of those broadly called Sephardim?
What does Mizrach mean in Hebrew?
How many major groups do the Ashkenazim belong to?
What does Ashkenaz mean in German?

plausible_answers.text: Mizrahi Jewish groups and Sephardi Jews

qas.question: What two groups are not ethnically distinct?

context: Jews are often identified as belonging to one of <b5_0>two<b5_0/> major groups: the <a0_0>Ashkenazim<a0_0/> and the <a1_0>Sephardim<a1_0/>. Ashkenazim, or "Germanics" (Ashkenaz meaning "<a2_0><b7_0>Germany<b7_0/><a2_0/>" in Hebrew), are so named denoting their German Jewish cultural and geographical origins, while Sephardim, or "Hispanics" (<b8_0>Sefarad<b8_0/> meaning "Spain/Hispania" or "Iberia" in Hebrew), are so named denoting their Spanish/Portuguese Jewish cultural and geographic origins. The more common term in Israel for many of those broadly called Sephardim, is <a3_0><b6_0>Mizrahim<b6_0/><a3_0/> (lit. "Easterners", Mizrach being "<a4_0>East<a4_0/>" in Hebrew), that is, in reference to the diverse collection of Middle Eastern and North African Jews who are often, as a group, referred to collectively as Sephardim (together with Sephardim proper) for liturgical reasons, although <b9_0>Mizrahi Jewish groups and Sephardi Jews<b9_0/> proper are ethnically distinct.
